newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK blue chips end weak as property stocks fall.
newsitem.headline: HK blue chips end weak as property stocks fall.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks erased the session's gains to end weaker on Tuesday, with investors selling down property stocks and turning their attention to second line counters, analysts said.
The Hang Seng Index fell 16.56 points, or 0.12 percent, to 13,252.20 after rising to a session high of 13,342.46. Turnover was HK$13.37 billion compared with HK$13.11 billion on Monday.
"It is a very weak market for blue-chip stocks and it has been the case for a while," said Frederick Tsang, head of research at PrimeEast Securities.
"People are selling blue chips to buy second liner stocks."
Property stocks led the blue-chip index lower on Tuesday, shrugging off a new record high on Wall Street. The Dow industrials rose 78.50 points on Monday to an all-time closing high of 7,079.39.
Shares in Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd fell HK$0.75 to HK$73.50 and Henderson Land Development Co finished down HK$0.50 at HK$67.50.
"The property market went up a lot and a lot of investors are worried about whether prices are sustainable," said Patrick Chia, research director at China Everbright Research.
"Another thing is interest rate worries. There are worries that a rate hike will happen later on," he added.
Among the red chips, First Shanghai Investments Ltd soared HK$0.13 to HK$0.99 and China Resources Beijing Land Ltd rose HK$0.05 to HK$5.55.
"I guess there are some rumours about an upcoming interest rate cut in China and there are a lot of rumours about asset injections on a number of red chips," said Chia.
Brokers said investors were looking to make quick gains in the second line counters.
"Despite the risk, it gives investors a way to make a quick 20 or 30 percent," said Kent Rossiter, institutional sales manager at Nikko Securities.

Shum Yip Investment Ltd succumbed to profit-taking following a surge in its share price since its listing last Friday. The stock ended on a loss of HK$0.325 at HK$4.975. Its initial public offering was launched at HK$1.85 per share.
Shangri-La Asia Ltd fell HK$0.20 to HK$9.25. The hotel operator is due to release its 1996 results on Friday and analysts expect net profit growth of about 21 percent.
Shares in HSBC Holdings Plc rose HK$1.50 to HK$191.50 and Hang Seng Bank Ltd added HK$0.50 to HK$84.75.
